BTSBM: Bradley–Terry Stochastic Block Model 0.1.0

Relabel cluster assignments by decreasing lambda

Source: R/utils.R
relabel_by_lambda.Rd

Given posterior samples of labels x_samples (S x N) and corresponding cluster-level intensities lambda_samples per iteration, produce a canonical relabeling where cluster 1 has the largest \(\lambda\), cluster 2 the second largest, etc. Also computes co-clustering summaries and assignment probabilities.

Usage

relabel_by_lambda(x_samples, lambda_samples)

Arguments

x_samples

Integer matrix S x N of sampled labels (arbitrary ids per iter).

lambda_samples

Either:

  • a list of length S with numeric vectors indexed by raw label id (NAs allowed for non-occupied ids), or

  • a matrix S x L giving per-iteration \(\lambda_\ell\) for label \(\ell\).

Value

A list with components:

x_samples_relabel

S x N integer matrix of relabeled draws (1..K per iter, ordered by \(\lambda\)).

lambda_samples_relabel

S x N numeric matrix assigning each item its cluster's \(\lambda\) after relabeling.

item_cluster_assignment_probs

N x Kmax data frame of marginal assignment probabilities.

block_count_distribution

Data frame of the distribution of the number of blocks across iterations.

avg_top_block_count

Average size of the top-\(\lambda\) block.

co_clustering

Posterior similarity matrix (N x N).

minVI_partition

Hard partition via minVI.

partition_binder

Hard partition via Binder's loss.

n_clusters_each_iter

Integer vector length S with number of blocks per iteration.

top_block_count_per_iter

Integer vector length S with size of the top block per iteration.

cluster_lambda_ordered

List length S of ordered \(\lambda\) vectors (length K per iter).

Details

The function first compacts raw labels to 1..K within each iteration, then orders the occupied labels by decreasing \(\lambda\), producing a canonical labeling. Co-clustering summaries use mcclust and mcclust.ext.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
S <- 100; N <- 20
set.seed(42)
x_samps <- matrix(sample(1:3, S*N, TRUE), S, N)
lam_list <- replicate(S, { v <- rep(NA_real_, 5); v[1:3] <- runif(3, 0.5, 2); v }, simplify=FALSE)
out <- relabel_by_lambda(x_samps, lam_list)
table(out$block_count_distribution$num_blocks)
} # }
